user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_GetValueText:
```c
static const char *UtAssert_GetValueText(char *TempBuf, size_t TempSz, UT_IntCheck_t InValue, bool IsUnsigned,
                                         UtAssert_Radix_t RadixType)
{
    if (RadixType == UtAssert_Radix_BOOLEAN)
    {
        if (InValue != 0)
        {
            snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "true");
        }
        else
        {
            snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "false");
        }
    }
    else if (RadixType == UtAssert_Radix_OCTAL)
    {
        snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "0%lo", (unsigned long)InValue);
    }
    else if (RadixType == UtAssert_Radix_HEX)
    {
        snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "0x%lx", (unsigned long)InValue);
    }
    else if (IsUnsigned)
    {
        snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "%lu", (unsigned long)InValue);
    }
    else
    {
        snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "%ld", (long)InValue);
    }

    return TempBuf;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
snprintf(TempBuf, TempSz, "0x%lx", (unsigned long)InValue);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. The code does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. TempBuf is used as a modifiable destination for snprintf, so it must be a pointer to non-const data. A violation would occur if TempBuf were declared as const char * (or pointer to const) and then passed to snprintf (attempting to modify a const-qualified object).
